de89b0db-d3ac-4086-9e2e-6935383043dc.description: The TechSet program prepares college juniors and seniors to succeed as new employees in fast-moving technology jobs. We do this through a two-month program that emphasizes work readiness, job tools, and career preparation through mentorship and instruction from a teaching team with real-world experience and expertise. This badge shows that you completed this program, recognized by a growing group of regional employers as a strong indication of career readiness.
de89b0db-d3ac-4086-9e2e-6935383043dc.name: TechSet Ready Badge

badge_template_activities.title: Our program is prioritized for current college and university students who demonstrate an economic need (preferred, but not required), are classified as a junior or senior at any four-year college or university that serves Northern Virginia (including Region 7 DC universities), participate in at least 75% of classes and mentoring sessions, and are in good academic standing (minimum 2.0 GPA, not on probation or suspension).

b566c7d3-cb8c-4d90-aa97-434e3120d63f.description: Earners have the knowledge, skills, and abilities in basic descriptive and inferential statistical procedures used in the analysis of data. 09d98a81-6687-4cb2-a132-741a6e966f16.description: Earners have the knowledge, skills, and abilities in basic statistics and explore contemporary topics in the areas of data science and business analytics. The earners have knowledge of R, a robust, open-source statistical platform. The earners have insights into the application of data science to a variety of fields.
09d98a81-6687-4cb2-a132-741a6e966f16.name: Marymount University: Data Science & Machine Learning

d562482b-4cf5-46ff-a1df-55555ae940df.description: Earners of this badge have demonstrated in depth knowledge, skills, and abilities in system and network security, privacy, and the ethical and legal considerations in ensuring the security of digital technology. Earners have completed curriculum that aligns with the employer-validated, digital tech competencies required for jobs with Capital CoLAB employers.
d562482b-4cf5-46ff-a1df-55555ae940df.name: Cybersecurity Specialist Digital Technology Credential

badge_template_activities.title: IT120 Cybersecurity Principles: The course covers the major cybersecurity principles such as the CIA triangle and defense-in-depth as well as major attack vectors including malware, ransomware, insider threats, hacking, social engineering, and denial of services attacks.  It includes a general discuss of security controls including firewalls, access controls and encryption.  It introduces students to vulnerabilities and threats and the principles of risk management.

IT129 Python Scripting The course teaches students to code in Python.  Initially students cover the fundamentals of programming including syntax, variables, conditional branching, loops, and functions.  Students develop several programs to solve specific problems involving computations, data structures, user interfaces (input and output), and conditional, iterative and recursive structures.

IT205 Digital Technologies: The course introduces students to digital technology, from large networked systems in government and industry to day-to-day devices such as laptops and smartphones.  Students begin to understand the components of hardware and software, including basic programming techniques.  Students install hardware and software and examine the technical support role, including ticketing and customer service.  Students examine how computers work, including data encoding.

IT229 Advance Python Applications: The course builds on the student’s coding skills developed in IT 129.  They develop more sophisticated applications with more complex data structures and features such as logging capabilities to solve specific problems.  Performance and secure coding are considered in the application development.  Advanced techniques such as natural language processing (NLP) are also covered.

IT305 Computer Networking: The course enables students to apply networking fundamentals to the technology infrastructure.  It covers the protocols behind packet switching networks, the fundamental communication technology on the Internet.  It examines different media used to connect computers including fiber optics, copper cables, and wireless.  It includes a discussion of cybersecurity across all types of networks, including port security and allows students to experience network tools.

IT315 Operating Systems and Virtualization:  The course introduces the major functions of operating systems on a variety of devices (Windows, Unix, Android, iOS).  Students install these operating systems and maintain them through automated and manual patching.  The second part of the course covers virtualization and students install virtual machines on their own computers and on the cloud using tools such as VirtualBox and VMWare.  Students also investigate hypervisors.

IT321 Cloud Computing: The course covers the architecture of today’s cloud providers such as AWS, Azure, Google, IBM and Oracle.  It covers the fundamental cloud functions including processing, storage, networking, and emphasizes reliability, availability, and performance.  It describes the type of cloud (public, private, hybrid, etc.), the types of services (IaaS, PaaS, SaaS, etc.), and the components that make cloud computing work including load balancers, auto-escalation, and security.

IT335 Corporate Cybersecurity: The course reinforces many of the cybersecurity principles previously covered on IT120, focusing on implementing high levels of security in a corporate environment.  It reviews cybersecurity controls and the vulnerabilities and threats they address.  Students develop incident response processes, including the collection and analysis of logs, maintaining chain of custody, and situational awareness.  It examines network security devices such as firewalls and IDS/IPS.

IT351 Cloud Security and DevSecOps: The course covers the cybersecurity considerations which arise as companies move their technology assets to the cloud.  Cloudjacking and other threats are discussed and techniques to minimize such adverse attacks are examined, including the access controls on data buckets.  Students experiment in various cloud instances to maximize security.  Problem solving and visualization of potential solutions are also covered.

skills.name: Programming Fundamentals And Secure Software Design

3d0c88ca-7bf7-4a5c-86b5-0dbcf5eead3b.description: Earners of this badge have demonstrated in depth knowledge, skills, and abilities in system and network security, digital vulnerabilities and threats, incident response, and risk management. Earners have completed curriculum that aligns with the employer-validated, digital tech competencies required for jobs with Capital CoLAB employers.
3d0c88ca-7bf7-4a5c-86b5-0dbcf5eead3b.name: Cybersecurity Technologist Digital Technology Credential

IT205 Digital Technologies: The course introduces students to digital technology, from large networked systems in government and industry to day-to-day devices such as laptops and smartphones.  Students begin to understand the components of hardware and software, including basic programming techniques.  Students install hardware and software and examine the technical support role, including ticketing and customer service.  Students examine how computers work, including data encoding.

IT305 Computer Networking: The course enables students to apply networking fundamentals to the technology infrastructure.  It covers the protocols behind packet switching networks, the fundamental communication technology on the Internet.  It examines different media used to connect computers including fiber optics, copper cables, and wireless.  It includes a discussion of cybersecurity across all types of networks, including port security and allows students to experience network tools.

IT315 Operating Systems and Virtualization:  The course introduces the major functions of operating systems on a variety of devices (Windows, Unix, Android, iOS).  Students install these operating systems and maintain them through automated and manual patching.  The second part of the course covers virtualization and students install virtual machines on their own computers and on the cloud using tools such as VirtualBox and VMWare.  Students also investigate hypervisors.

IT321 Cloud Computing: The course covers the architecture of today’s cloud providers such as AWS, Azure, Google, IBM and Oracle.  It covers the fundamental cloud functions including processing, storage, networking, and emphasizes reliability, availability, and performance.  It describes the type of cloud (public, private, hybrid, etc.), the types of services (IaaS, PaaS, SaaS, etc.), and the components that make cloud computing work including load balancers, auto-escalation, and security.

IT335 Corporate Cybersecurity: The course reinforces many of the cybersecurity principles previously covered on IT120, focusing on implementing high levels of security in a corporate environment.  It reviews cybersecurity controls and the vulnerabilities and threats they address.  Students develop incident response processes, including the collection and analysis of logs, maintaining chain of custody, and situational awareness.  It examines network security devices such as firewalls and IDS/IPS.

IT351 Cloud Security and DevSecOps: The course covers the cybersecurity considerations which arise as companies move their technology assets to the cloud.  Cloudjacking and other threats are discussed and techniques to minimize such adverse attacks are examined, including the access controls on data buckets.  Students experiment in various cloud instances to maximize security.  Problem solving and visualization of potential solutions are also covered.

IT390 Cybersecurity Attack and Defend: The course focuses on tools and techniques that can be used to attack and defend technology.  Students apply a variety of open source tools, such as Kali Linux, to understand and mitigate threats.  They examine cyberthreat intelligence tools, SIEM technology, and the processes carried out in a Security Operation Center (SOC).  They install and configure network devices (such as switches and VPN concentrators) and network security devices.

c1315a9d-f0c0-47a8-bf11-267d29f10c17.description: Earners of this badge have demonstrated in depth knowledge, skills, and abilities in data analysis, visualization, manipulation, ethics, and security. Earners also have a fundamental knowledge of probability and statistics. Earners have completed curriculum that aligns with the employer-validated, digital tech competencies required for jobs with Capital CoLAB employers.
c1315a9d-f0c0-47a8-bf11-267d29f10c17.name: Data Analytics Digital Technology Credential

badge_template_activities.title: DATA325 Data Analytics: The course introduces students to the field of data analytics.  It starts with an understanding of data and the terminology used in its collection, storage, quality, validation, analysis and visualization.  The students review probability as well as descriptive and inferential statistics and develop models to illustrate their application.  The course includes a section on data ethics and the legal and regulatory compliance issues associated with data (e.g. medical data).

DATA395 Data Visualization: The course examines the role of data visualization in communicating the results of data analysis.  Students use a variety of tools such as MS Excel, Tableau, and MS PowerBI to create a variety of displays including dashboards, graphs, tables, maps, and infographics.  Students create data visualizations for a wide set of audiences from data sets of various types.

IT210 Software Engineering: The course introduces students to the entire software development process from requirements gathering to software in the production environment.  It discusses modeling in terms of the traditional system development life cycles such as Waterfall, as well as modern techniques such as Agile and DevOps.  Tools and technologies are examined and applications are taken through the entire lifecycle.  Communication (oral and writing) and teamwork are emphasized.

IT310 Database Technology: The course examines the increasing role of data in business and society and focuses on its storage for fast, on-demand retrieval.  It covers a wide variety of data typologies (structured, unstructured, text, numeric, etc.).  Students analyze data diagramming both logical and physical designs, including normalization.

IT385 Managing Big Data: This course applies the knowledge garnered in IT310 to very large and complex data sets.  It begins with a discussion of data governance, including change management, and maintaining quality throughout the data life cycle.  On-premise and cloud methodologies are discussed.  The course allows students to handle large data sets, throughout their lifecycle resulting in subsequent meaningful data analysis.

92687f32-27f9-4f8a-8158-41da2aa9423d.description: Earners of this badge have demonstrated fundamental knowledge, skills, and abilities in data analysis, data visualization, and data security. Earners have completed curriculum that aligns with the employer-validated, digital tech competencies required for jobs with Capital CoLAB employers.
92687f32-27f9-4f8a-8158-41da2aa9423d.name: Generalist Digital Technology Credential

badge_template_activities.title: IT120 Cybersecurity Principles: The course covers the major cybersecurity principles such as the CIA triangle and defense-in-depth as well as major attack vectors including malware, ransomware, insider threats, hacking, social engineering, and denial of services attacks.  It includes a general discuss of security controls including firewalls, access controls and encryption.  It introduces students to vulnerabilities and threats and the principles of risk management.

IT310 Database Technology: The course examines the increasing role of data in business and society and focuses on its storage for fast, on-demand retrieval.  It covers a wide variety of data typologies (structured, unstructured, text, numeric, etc.).  Students analyze data diagramming both logical and physical designs, including normalization.

DATA310 Decision Analysis: The course focuses on the use of data to reduce the risk and uncertainty in decision-making.  It first reviews probability and statistics, including linear regression.  Students conduct a series of analysis including summarization, estimation, prediction, and using pivot tables.  Data security is also covered in terms of sensitivity and risk factors.

DATA325 Data Analytics: The course introduces students to the field of data analytics.  It starts with an understanding of data and the terminology used in its collection, storage, quality, validation, analysis and visualization.  The students review probability as well as descriptive and inferential statistics and develop models to illustrate their application.  The course includes a section on data ethics and the legal and regulatory compliance issues associated with data (e.g. medical data).

IT385 Managing Big Data: This course applies the knowledge garnered in IT310 to very large and complex data sets.  It begins with a discussion of data governance, including change management, and maintaining quality throughout the data life cycle.  On-premise and cloud methodologies are discussed.  The course allows students to handle large data sets, throughout their lifecycle resulting in subsequent meaningful data analysis.

DATA395 Data Visualization: The course examines the role of data visualization in communicating the results of data analysis.  Students use a variety of tools such as MS Excel, Tableau, and MS PowerBI to create a variety of displays including dashboards, graphs, tables, maps, and infographics.  Students create data visualizations for a wide set of audiences from data sets of various types.

793e3bf0-a938-47c2-bdd2-132b63fb79a4.description: Earners of this badge have demonstrated in depth knowledge, skills, and abilities in machine learning models, algorithms, mathematical and statistical machine learning, and data ethics. Earners have completed curriculum that aligns with the employer-validated, digital tech competencies required for jobs with Capital CoLAB employers.
793e3bf0-a938-47c2-bdd2-132b63fb79a4.name: Machine Learning Digital Technology Credential

badge_template_activities.title: DATA325 Data Analytics: The course introduces students to the field of data analytics.  It starts with an understanding of data and the terminology used in its collection, storage, quality, validation, analysis and visualization.  The students review probability as well as descriptive and inferential statistics and develop models to illustrate their application.  The course includes a section on data ethics and the legal and regulatory compliance issues associated with data (e.g. medical data).

DATA370 Machine Learning Technologies: The course enables student to learn how machine learning works and when it can be used.  Key terms are introduced including supervised and unsupervised learning.  Different techniques are explored.  Deep learning architectures are also described.  Machine learning models and algorithms are applied and their performance evaluated.  A model is trained and used to make predictions.  Issues with machine learning are discussed including trustworthiness and bias.

DATA395 Data Visualization: The course examines the role of data visualization in communicating the results of data analysis.  Students use a variety of tools such as MS Excel, Tableau, and MS PowerBI to create a variety of displays including dashboards, graphs, tables, maps, and infographics.  Students create data visualizations for a wide set of audiences from data sets of various types.

IT385 Managing Big Data: The course applies the knowledge garnered in IT310 to very large and complex data sets.  It begins with a discussion of data governance, including change management, and maintaining quality throughout the data life cycle.  On-premise and cloud methodologies are discussed.  The course allows students to handle large data sets, throughout their lifecycle resulting in subsequent meaningful data analysis.
